body:
Are you uploading lots of small files? That is the worst case for drive.

Google has a lot of rate limiting, per client, per application per cluster as far as I can see.  You can get caught up in one of those rate limits. rclone has 1 billion operations per day quota from google and it is using nothing like that.

The Google drive client uses a different API to the one rclone uses an unpublished one :-(

Some people have reported that adding their own credentials does help - I'd be interested to hear if it does.
Yes, i am uploading a lot of files. I created a new entity in the developer console and now i am waiting for the response of the google team to increase my limits. I will post my results.
You could also try increasing `--transfers` to see if that helps.

I tried to ad client_id and client_secret created with my user. And if i now try to authenticate i get a 
 Failed to configure token: failed to get token: oauth2: cannot fetch token: 401 Unauthorized

The type is still drive.

Starting today, Google Drive became so slow that every attempt to copy to Google Drive would fail, never getting past the stage of "building file list", even if I set a large number of retries.  It repeatedly produced rateLimitExceeded errors.  Listing a directory at times was as slow as about one file per second.

So I set up my own client ID, and now things are working alright.  A couple of weeks ago I was getting 25 MB/s uploads. I'm getting 1.3 MB/s uploads now, but that might be because I'm uploading a lot of small files at the moment.

@balazer , Could you please add some details how you got client_id and client_secret ? I have tried to create one following these guidelines, but I am lost ! https://developers.google.com/identity/sign-in/web/devconsole-project
Thanks in advance ;)

Very useful information thanks @balazer 

I can see myself that it is running extremely slowly now :-(

I'll try tweaking the parameters of the rate limiter and see if I can improve things.  I suspect I might need to talk to someone at google to resolve the problem though.

If someone wanted to contribute a tutorial or list of instructions on how to get your own developer ID then I can include them in the rclone docs.

issue.title: I want to copy only new files. Why is this action so slow?

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
is:open label:question 

I got a boxcryptor container on google (1,7GB, approx 5k files) and i what to have a dump of the container on my NAS (the idea is to dump it every 30 min) to have a own history using rsnapshot on the local container.

so my idea was to run:
`
rclone copy dave_kr8: /media/dave.kr8@drive.google.com/ --low-level-retries 20 --retries 20
`
with a cronjob every 30 min. unfortunately i got end up with
`
2016/07/13 05:59:18
Transferred:            0Bytes (0Byte/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:     25m8.8s
`
when i added just one file to the container.

so from my point of view, getting a filelist from the google api is fast, comparing time and size is fast, too.
what is wasting so much time? is it recalculating hashes?

how can i reduce the time for "copying" (the copy command) only a few new files every 30 min?

i appreciate if one can give me a more detailed insight in what is going on behind the rclone command. 

_Edit:_

*\* hmmm, my nas is running on a ssd, and i use the noatime option to mount my filesystem. maybe this is the problem i am facing???

*\* but it's the same result if i use  --checksum oder --size-only command. or is the copy command not using the options?

body:
https://console.developers.google.com
- [ ]  Select a project
  - [ ]  Create a project ...
    - fill in : Project name, etc, confirm.
      done !
- [ ]  API Manager 
  - [ ]  Overview
    - [ ]  Google Apps APIs
      - [ ]  Drive API
      - Enable
      - [ ]  Go to Credentials 
      - Google Drive API
      - Other UI
      - User data
      
      No need to be specific with the data ! 

Result:
**Client ID
Client secret**

To create your own Google Drive client ID for rclone:
1. Log into the Google API Console at https://console.developers.google.com/ with your Google account. It doesn't matter what Google account you use. (It need not be the same account as the Google Drive you want to access)
2. Select a project or create a new project.
3. Under Overview, Google APIs, Google Apps APIs, click "Drive API", then "Enable". 
4. Click "Credentials" in the left-side panel (not "Go to credentials", which opens the wizard), then "Create credentials", then "OAuth client ID".  It will prompt you to set the OAuth consent screen product name, if you haven't set one already.
5. Choose an application type of  "other", and click "Create". (the default name is fine)
6. It will show you a client ID and client secret.  Use these values in rclone config to add a new remote or edit an existing remote.

Many thanks @balazer & @davekr8 ! ;) 
I don't which method is the best, but I have just tested @balazer 's one and it seems to work fine for me so far. ;)
Many thanks to both of you for the help. I much appreciated. ;)
**edit:** A few minutes later I had several errors ("error" : "unauthorized_client") so I had to also update the token inside rclone config. All is working fine now. ;)
edit2 : in my case " (the default name is fine)" I choosed one like "Rcloneme" so it will be much easier later to avoid removing accidentally the correct one from Google Account/ Apps connected.

well, i am running rclone on my own api keys and i realized a large ratio of 
client errors / successfull request (s.below). 

is the a possible feature in the drive api to lower the erroneous payload of requests ? that would be great, for efficiency ; )

![stats](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12131511/16871437/2d5e79be-4a87-11e6-9198-5509760dbd13.jpg)

The client errors are almost certainly 403 - rate limit exceeded.  That is drive's way of telling rclone to back off. There are lots of rate limits in drive - a per project one which isn't listed in the developers console and uploads per second and other invisible limits.

rclone tries to send stuff quickly, then backs off as it receives 403 errors.  This is the way it is supposed to work, but it is a bit annoying!

i realized that mainly the checkers causes my errors ... reducing them to 2 completely avoids the 403 type...

but i thought of using batch type of requests (s. [https://developers.google.com/drive/v3/web/batch](https://developers.google.com/drive/v3/web/batch) for details). i haven't any idea if you already considered that design pattern of batch-requests in your code, or if it is too specific as only drive use it, to integrate it. but from my point of view, for drive it would be worth to give a try. 

_edit:
by the way, i again have to say, that i appreciate the work you do. i am getting a real fan of rclone. it's a great tool._

The upload limit is very curious since there seems to not be a download rate limit. I can only upload around 200Mbps max and can saturate my 1Gbps download.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/hsa4in3mysr7m6a/Screen%20Shot%202016-07-23%20at%2011.13.16%20AM.png?dl=0

The google developers told me that there are lots of other invisible (to me) rate limits.  I'm pretty sure one at least is uploads/second.  I would be suprised if another limited the total upload rate - I've never exceeded 200 Mbit/s on our 1 Gbit/s connection at work either.

@Nick

Was there a throttle option? I assumed -bw-limit option was a throttle
option eg #mbps , #kbps.

Regards,
Zeshan
